proposals.reasoning: I want to avoid bundling Alice and Bob on the very first mission so we preserve contrast for later reads. Starting with Bob + Diana gives us an early baseline on two players who were both open to being on the first team but with slightly different preferences, and it lets us see how the table reacts to a team that leaves the initial proposer (Alice) off without immediately concentrating both of the most vocal players on one mission.

votes.comment: Reasonable contrast-based first team; I’m fine staying off early to gather reactions.
As good, I’m fine taking an early baseline mission I’m on; no strong reason yet to distrust Diana or delay info.

I’d prefer a first mission that includes at least one of Alice or me for better early info; putting Bob+Diana together sidelines both original proposer and another vocal player, which feels unnecessarily low‑info.
Matches my earlier preference to avoid bundling Alice and Bob immediately and gives us a low-drama baseline with split vocal/quiet roles.
I proposed this composition for contrast info and should stay consistent with that logic now.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d rather keep the first team simple and low‑drama—something like me plus one of the more talkative players (maybe Bob) so we at least get some reads from how people react. If anyone has a strong preference for a different pairing, I’d like to hear the reasoning now instead of after the fact.

I’m fine being the “talkative plus one” if you want to start Alice + Bob, but I’d also be okay with you pairing yourself with someone quieter like Diana so we can compare how people react to a low‑info vs. high‑info team.

I’d lean Alice + Bob to start, since having two vocal people on the first mission gives us more to analyze from both the team choice and the votes. If anyone’s strongly against that pair, I’d like to hear why before we lock it in.
I’m okay with Alice + Bob, but I slightly prefer starting with Bob + me so we don’t auto‑bundle the two most vocal players on the very first mission and can compare how people treat that team.

I’d rather not bundle Alice and Bob right away since that gives us less contrast later—Bob + Diana feels like a cleaner baseline first test, and we can see who’s eager or hesitant about leaving Alice off.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 was a clean success with Bob and Diana, so it’s reasonable to assume at least one of them is good. I don’t want to auto-lock the Bob+Diana pair yet, so I’m keeping exactly one of them (Bob) and adding two new people (myself and Charlie) to generate fresh info. This lines up with what several people suggested: mix the proven pool with new blood rather than re-running the same combination, while not over-indexing on Eve as leader from Mission 1. If this team stays clean, we’ll have a strong core of likely goods going into later missions; if there’s a fail, we get a focused set of suspects without having committed to the Bob+Diana pair as untouchable.

votes.comment: I’m on this team, and it keeps exactly one of the prior mission’s members while adding new info without looking suspicious.
Includes me plus two untested players, gives strong info either way without re-locking the Bob+Diana pair.
Team is info-rich and includes me; with Bob from a clean mission plus two new players, any fail gives very focused suspects, and if it passes we establish a strong likely-good core.
I’d rather not have two completely untested players on a 3‑person team; I’d feel better keeping both from the clean first mission (Bob and Diana) and adding just one new person for info.
This matches what I advocated—good info and I’m off team while an ally is on it.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’m inclined to keep at least one of Bob/Diana on the team, but I’d really like to see a new person (including me) added so we’re not blindly locking in the same pair as auto‑trusted.

I like the idea of mixing it up a bit—between me and Diana you’ve probably got at least one good, so I’d go with one of us plus you, Alice, and then choose the third from Charlie/Eve based on who feels more consistent so far.
I’m fine assuming at least one of Bob/Diana is good, but I’d rather run a team like Alice + me + exactly one of them so we get fresh info instead of locking in that pair too fast.

Given Eve already led the first one, I’d slightly prefer a team from Bob/Diana/Charlie this round—something like Bob + Charlie + me feels like a reasonable, low‑risk way to get fresh info without over‑trusting the leader slot.

Given the clean first mission, I’d rather not lock in both Bob and Diana together again—something like Alice + Bob + Charlie feels like a good way to keep at least one “likely good” while still getting fresh info. I’m fine sitting out here so we’re not just re‑running the same trust loop around my first‑mission choice.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s fail can only come from Alice or Charlie (I know I’m good), so the safest approach this round is to avoid both of them entirely. That leaves Bob, Diana, and Eve as candidates. Any 2-person team that excludes me has a higher chance of containing at least one unknown evil; statistically, including myself plus one of the remaining players (Diana or Eve) is strictly safer than pairing two unknowns together (like Diana + Eve). Between those, Bob + Diana is the only pair with a past clean result (Mission 1 succeeded with exactly this combo), which at least shows this team has produced a success before, even if it doesn’t hard-clear anyone. So the best balance of risk and prior evidence is to re-run Bob + Diana and keep both Alice and Charlie off this mission.

votes.comment: I still prefer a Diana + Eve reset that fully avoids the failed Mission 2 team; reusing Bob + Diana doesn’t give us new info and still leaves Bob as an unproven risk from my perspective.

From my POV the fail on Mission 2 is Alice or Charlie, so keeping both off is priority. Reusing Bob+Diana—our only previously successful pair—is safer than introducing Alice/Charlie risk or an untested Diana+Eve combo.

From my perspective the fail on Mission 2 had to come from Alice or Bob, and since I know I’m good, Bob is highly suspect; I’d rather avoid both Alice and Bob this round and prefer a Diana+Eve team instead.
This keeps both suspects from the failed Mission 2 (Alice and Charlie) off the team and reuses the only previously successful pair, which is about as safe as we can get right now.
Reusing Bob from the failed Mission 2 doesn’t feel as safe as a fresh pair like Diana + me that fully avoids the last fail’s participants.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had a single fail with Alice, Bob, and me on it, so at least one of Alice or Bob must be evil from my perspective, since I know I’m good. The safest move for a 2-player mission is therefore to avoid both Alice and Bob entirely. That leaves Diana and Eve as the only pair completely untouched by the failed mission. Sending Diana + Eve both maximizes our chance of a clean success this round and gives strong alignment information: if they pass, the evil team is almost certainly within Alice/Bob; if they fail, we know at least one of them is evil and can cross-check that with the prior failure on Mission 2 for later rounds.

votes.comment: Includes Eve and keeps suspicion focused on the Alice/Bob/Charlie group after the last fail.

From my POV, at least one of Alice/Charlie is evil from Mission 2’s single fail, and I know I’m good. That means the second evil must be in {Diana, Eve}, so a Diana+Eve team is guaranteed to include exactly one evil and is too risky to send.
From my POV the Mission 2 fail is Alice or Bob, so a Diana+Eve team that avoids both is the safest, most informative option right now.
I still prefer reusing the Bob+Diana pair from the only clean mission we have rather than introducing an untested player like Eve on a tiny 2-person team.
Consistent with my earlier stance that a fresh Diana+Eve team avoids all suspects from the failed Mission 2 and gives strong info either way.

discussion.content: Given the single fail on the last mission, I’d rather see a clean reset with two people who weren’t on that team, so something like Diana + Eve feels safest right now, while Alice/Bob/Charlie are all a bit suspect from that result.
I’m fine sitting out here—since I know I’m good, that fail on Mission 2 has to be Alice or Charlie (or both), so I like a Diana + Eve team for this round.

I get the logic of a Diana + Eve reset since they’re the only pair untouched by the fail, but if we do that and it somehow fails, I’m looking hard at Alice/Bob coordination here. For now I’m okay approving Diana + Eve unless someone has a strong reason to doubt either of them.

Given Mission 1 with Bob and me is our only fully clean pair so far, I’d feel better about a 2-person team like Bob + Diana than pairing two people who’ve never been tested together. If we want to minimize risk this round, reusing the one proven-success combo seems more solid than a fresh Diana + Eve.

I’m leaning toward Diana + me here—Mission 1 only proves Bob/Diana worked once, not that Bob is cleared, and a fresh pair that avoids all of Alice/Bob/Charlie feels like the lowest-risk way to get new info without repeating the team that just produced a fail.

proposals.reasoning: Both failed missions are tied to the Alice/Bob/Charlie cluster on Mission 2 and the Diana/Eve cluster on Mission 3. To avoid repeating either suspicious pair (Alice–Bob or Diana–Eve), this team uses at most one player from each cluster while still including people who have been on a successful mission. Leaving both Alice and Eve off reduces overlap with prior fails and gives us a new, more balanced combination for a must-pass mission.

votes.comment: If we believe exactly one evil in Alice/Bob/Charlie and one in Diana/Eve, this team (Bob/Charlie/Diana) risks putting both non-Alice evils together or creating a fully good team we can’t verify; I’d prefer including at least one of Alice or Eve for better info alignment with prior missions.
Too much risk with Charlie and Diana together; many likely evil pairings include at least one of them, so this team is more likely than not to contain an evil.

Given the structure (1 evil among Alice/Bob/Charlie and 1 among Diana/Eve), this team is only fully good in a narrow case. I currently lean toward Eve being the evil in the Diana/Eve pair, which would make this team fine there, but I’m not comfortable enough with Bob in the Alice/Bob/Charlie trio to risk a must-pass mission on this combination.
This avoids both suspicious pairs from the prior fails (Alice–Bob and Diana–Eve) and keeps Eve off while using a new combination that still includes players from the successful first mission.
This is a must-fail mission for evil and this team has no overlap with known suspicious players from the last fail, so it’s too likely to be clean and succeed.

proposals.reasoning: Given the two failed missions, I argued earlier that I don’t like putting Diana straight back on after the last fail and that I’d be more comfortable sitting out myself. Alice and Bob were together on the earlier failed mission, but that team also included Charlie, and we can’t conclusively pin the blame on a specific player from that one fail alone. This team matches both my prior stated preference (Alice, Bob, Charlie with me out) and fits reasonably with several others’ suggestions that center around Bob plus members who aren’t in the most suspicious recent pairing of Diana and me. It should be acceptable enough to get approved while avoiding immediately repeating the most suspect combinations.

votes.comment: This avoids the Diana/Eve pair that just failed and matches several players’ stated preferences around centering Bob while not repeating the most suspicious recent combination.
There must be exactly one evil in {Alice,Bob,Charlie} and one in {Diana,Eve}, and I know I’m good, so this team (Alice,Bob,Charlie) is guaranteed to contain exactly one evil and is too risky to send.

Logic shows every possible 3-person team must contain at least one of the four suspects (Alice, Bob, Diana, Eve), and under all consistent worlds this particular team always has exactly one evil, never two. Mixed teams (e.g. including both a suspect from Alice/Bob and from Diana/Eve) can easily contain two evils. Given prior rejection of Bob/Charlie/Diana and high suspicion on Diana, Alice–Bob–Charlie is the least-bad, single-evil-guaranteed option, so I’ll approve and hope the evil on it chooses to pass.
I still don’t want to repeat the Alice/Bob/Charlie cluster from the earlier fail; I’d prefer a team that changes that core rather than re-running it.

This matches my previously stated preference (Alice, Bob, Charlie with me out). With Diana/Eve suspected as a pair and no conclusive read from the earlier ABC fail, this is a plausible, consistent team for me to support.

discussion.content: Given the double dip on fails with Diana/Eve, I really don’t want them both on the next team again; I’d lean toward starting from Bob plus one of them, and then someone who hasn’t been as tied to the failed missions.

Given the two fails, I don’t want Diana and Eve together again, and I also don’t love fully repeating Alice/Bob/Charlie, so I’d start from me plus Alice and then decide between Charlie and Diana, with Eve sitting this one out.
From the patterns so far, I really don’t want both Alice and Bob together or Diana and Eve together on this team; I’d lean toward something like me, Alice, and Diana, with Eve sitting out.

Given the two failed missions, I really don’t want to repeat either the Alice/Bob cluster or the Diana/Eve cluster, so I’d most trust a team of Bob, Charlie, and me this time with both Alice and Eve sitting out.
Given the two fails, I really don’t like putting Diana back on after the last one, so I’d be more comfortable with something like Alice, Bob, and Charlie while I sit this one out.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my Mission 2 fail well and kept my story consistent enough that suspicion stayed spread rather than focused solely on me. I could improve by more actively guiding table talk and framing narratives earlier, instead of mostly reacting to others’ reads, to better protect Diana as Merlin and make Bob/Charlie look worse.

player_observations.Bob: Played very straightforwardly and honestly, which made his eventual suspicion feel more like a product of game state than his own defense or persuasion; he didn’t push hard narratives, so others could define how he was perceived.
player_observations.Charlie: Tended to over-explain and justify his reasoning, which paradoxically made him look more suspicious when on failed teams; he seemed to trust logic over social reads, making him vulnerable to subtle framing.
player_observations.Diana: Very controlled and careful with her accusations, nudging people in the right direction without over-committing; her restraint in hard-clearing anyone helped her stay under the radar as Merlin.
player_observations.Eve: Confident in proposing teams and comfortable taking social leadership, which made her an effective partner in getting critical fails through; she balanced sounding ‘reasonable’ with just enough flexibility to avoid being locked in as evil too early.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped secure the first success, but I didn’t push hard enough to re-evaluate Alice after the second fail, which let the same suspicious team composition through on Mission 4. I should have been more vocal about alternative teams (especially including Diana), and more systematic about tracking who was on which failed missions.

player_observations.Alice: Comfortably volunteered for risky teams and stayed calm after fails, which helped her maintain trust and keep getting picked despite being on multiple failed missions.
player_observations.Charlie: Played cautiously and seemed unsure about pushing accusations, which made him look more towny but also meant he didn’t strongly disrupt the evil-driven team proposals.
player_observations.Diana: Her suggestions tended to avoid repeat-fail configurations and subtly pointed in good directions, fitting a low-key Merlin style that tried not to draw direct aggro.
player_observations.Eve: Led mission selections in a way that kept at least one evil-aligned player on key teams and used early success (Mission 1) to build a trustworthy image before steering later fails.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Bob early but failed to follow through on that read when it mattered, especially on Missions 3 and 4. I should have been more suspicious of Alice after the Mission 2 fail and more protective of Diana, whose consistent logic and caution were strong Merlin signals I didn’t fully act on.

player_observations.Alice: Played aggressively but with just enough apparent self-critique to seem towny, using the Mission 2 fail to create confusion without drawing too much heat. Comfortable sitting on mixed teams and letting others argue, which helped her avoid being hard-cleared or hard-accused.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as straightforward and sincere, often accepting reasonable teams and not over-pushing his own agenda. His low-drama style made him easy to trust, but he could project his reasoning a bit more strongly to sway others.
player_observations.Diana: Showed careful, structured reasoning and often seemed to be nudging toward better team compositions without over-claiming certainty, which was very Merlin-like in hindsight. She was cautious in accusations, preferring to guide rather than dominate, which made her reads easy to underappreciate.
player_observations.Eve: Used her early leadership to establish credibility with a clean Mission 1, then later leveraged that trust to sell risky teams. Stayed calm and flexible, willing to work with multiple narratives so that she remained a comfortable, default approve for too many players.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly identified Alice and Eve as evil fairly early, but I struggled to communicate that information subtly enough for my team to trust me without tipping off the assassin. I should have been more consistent and deliberate in steering teams away from Alice on Missions 2 and 4 while creating clearer, believable town-logic reasons for trusting Bob and Charlie. Next time, I need to better balance my caution about being revealed as Merlin with more proactive guidance on team composition.

player_observations.Alice: Plays a very calm, low-drama evil game, leaning on plausible logic and letting others over-explain or tie themselves in knots, which makes her look naturally reasonable. She’s comfortable going on teams repeatedly and using partial truth to pad her arguments, which makes it hard for good to isolate her without strong meta-reads.
player_observations.Bob: Tends to play straightforward and somewhat trusting, which is good for table harmony but can leave him vulnerable to being steered by confident evil players. When suspicious, he hesitates to push very hard, so his doubts don’t always translate into strong votes or persuasive table talk.
player_observations.Charlie: Approaches the game analytically and tries to justify decisions with clear reasoning, which is very helpful for good when he’s on the right track. However, he can get anchored on early assumptions, making it easier for evil to exploit his initial reads if they’re even slightly off.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she stayed socially central but not overly loud, which helped her gather information about who might be Merlin without drawing suspicion. She was willing to take leadership spots and put together subtly compromised teams, and her kill choice showed she paid careful attention to who was nudging votes and team choices just a bit more than others.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed convincingly flexible between missions, leading two teams without drawing heavy suspicion and helping coordinate just enough fails to win without overexposing evil. I could improve by more explicitly steering suspicion toward a single, consistent ‘fake Merlin’ target earlier so that the endgame assassin shot would have been more cleanly justified rather than somewhat shared across multiple suspects.

player_observations.Alice: Played a low-key but effective evil game, blending into good logic and slipping a fail on Mission 2 without becoming the primary suspect, which helped keep attention spread out. Tended to follow group consensus rather than drive it, which made her look more like a cautious good player than a central evil force.
player_observations.Bob: Came across as genuinely good and somewhat straightforward, often trusting mission compositions a bit more than a paranoid player would, which made him less likely to be seen as evil but also less influential on team-building. His voting and table talk felt consistent, which made him a relatively safe person to include on teams once others attracted suspicion.
player_observations.Charlie: Showed a more analytical tendency, especially around missions 2 and 3, trying to reason from fail patterns and team overlaps, though not always pushing those conclusions forcefully. Occasionally second-guessed himself, which reduced his impact on steering the table but also kept him from being easily read as either strongly good or strongly evil.
player_observations.Diana: Subtly guided team selections and reads without over-asserting, which is very Merlin-like—she nudged away from some dangerous configurations but did it in a way that looked like normal deduction. Her comments were usually well-timed and grounded in mission data, making her seem like a strong, observant good player rather than a loud leader, which was a key indicator of hidden information.
